narratives.question_text: If a requirement, did this course occur in proper sequence within the School's educational program?  If not, where should it occur?
Comment on the body of material presented and the content of the course: sequence, syllabus, and assignments.
comments: All excellent, but for grad students, mid term and final exams are a nuisance, since they are not the reason for taking the class.

I thought the chronological organization was appropriate as well as the use of the two main books - one on cities and one on suburbs. My only suggestion would be that there was a lot of overlap between the material in Prof Hayden's book and the lectures on those topics. I also noticed that a lot of the readings dated to the '80s and I was curious about more recent scholarship. Overall though this was a very useful survey course. The deadlines for the draft and paper were early but well appreciated, and I think the requirement to turn in a draft was extremely useful. I'm a little less certain of the value of taking blue book exams at the graduate level, though they did help to synthesize the material.

narratives.question_text: What were your expectations for this course and how well were they met?
comments: To explore the social history of America's cities and landscape. Expectations were met.
My expectations for the course were well met, particularly in the opportunity to write a research paper and get significant feedback on it at the proposal, draft, and final stages.

narratives.question_text: Comment on the value of this course to you.
comments: This course was valuable in providing a broad overview of the American cultural landscape and illuminating the connections between land use policies and other trends over time. It provided an excellent foundation for future work.

narratives.question_text: Comment on the effectiveness of the teaching by the courses's instructor
comments: I wish Prof. Hayden had participated at times in the seminars, even though the TF was excellent at leading discussions. There was a bit of a disconnect between the readings assigned and the lectures.

While lectures sometimes repeated information in the readings, Professor Hayden was an excellent resource outside of class. She is extremely knowledgeable about this subject and managed to fit a lot of information into a limited number of lectures.

narratives.question_text: Suggestions you may have for course improvements:
comments: For grad students, i would recommend not having the exams as a requirement and increasing the length of the essay instead. Every-once-in-a-while some time needs to be spent on connecting themes in the class would be useful for students to be able to consider new materials in perspective.
My suggestion would be to eliminate some of the overlap between lectures and readings and include more recent articles in the readings.
